title: The Role of Obesity, Type 2 Diabetes, and Metabolic Factors in Pancreatic Cancer: A Mendelian Randomization Study
journal: Journal of the National Cancer Institute
author: Carreras-Torres
author_address: Section of Genetics, International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), Lyon, France
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on cancer
rationale: Risk factors for pancreatic cancer include a cluster of metabolic conditions such as obesity, hypertension, dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and type 2 diabetes. Given that these risk factors are correlated, separating out causal from confounded effects is challenging.
exposure_independence: Auhors state GWAS independence threshold. Do not do formal test.
exposure_proxy: Allowed for ambiguos strans but not discussed for other SNPs
n_SNP_difference_reason: Said they used European SNPs but clearly using all ancestry SNPs - though 1 is missing which isn't discussed
power_calculation_how: Power calculations on MR analyses were performed according to Burgess
multiple_testing: Not discussed
limitations_overall: Underpowered for WHR. Deviations from the MR assumptions would bias results to the null. Effects may not be reflective of the extremes of exposure distributions.
limitations_pleiotropy: MR Egger and weighted median did not show evidence of pleiotropy. Neither did funnel plots.
limitations_statistical_power: Not discussed, but sia dthey were underpowered for WHR

title: The Role of Obesity, Type 2 Diabetes, and Metabolic Factors in Pancreatic Cancer: A Mendelian Randomization Study
journal: Journal of the National Cancer Institute
author: Carreras-Torres
author_address: Section of Genetics, International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), Lyon, France
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on cancer
rationale: Risk factors for pancreatic cancer include a cluster of metabolic conditions such as obesity, hypertension, dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and type 2 diabetes. Given that these risk factors are correlated, separating out causal from confounded effects is challenging.
exposure_independence: Auhors state GWAS independence threshold. Do not do formal test.
exposure_proxy: Allowed for ambiguos strans but not discussed for other SNPs
n_SNP_difference_reason: Said they used European SNPs but clearly using all ancestry SNPs - only included SNPs that clustered in Neuronal developmental processes
power_calculation_how: Power calculations on MR analyses were performed according to Burgess
multiple_testing: Bonferroni correction for 157 tests (tests included for other phenotypes such as height) = 3.2x10-4
limitations_overall: Underpowered for WHR. Deviations from the MR assumptions would bias results to the null. Effects may not be reflective of the extremes of exposure distributions.
limitations_pleiotropy: MR Egger and weighted median did not show evidence of pleiotropy. Neither did funnel plots.
limitations_statistical_power: Not discussed, but sia dthey were underpowered for WHR

n_SNP_difference_reason: Said they used European SNPs but clearly using all ancestry SNPs - only included SNPs that clustered in Monogenic Obesity and or Energy Homeostasis
power_calculation_how: Power calculations on MR analyses were performed according to Burgess
multiple_testing: Bonferroni correction for 157 tests (tests included for other phenotypes such as height) = 3.2x10-4
limitations_overall: Underpowered for WHR. Deviations from the MR assumptions would bias results to the null. Effects may not be reflective of the extremes of exposure distributions.
limitations_pleiotropy: MR Egger and weighted median did not show evidence of pleiotropy. Neither did funnel plots.
limitations_statistical_power: Not discussed, but sia dthey were underpowered for WHR

title: The Role of Obesity, Type 2 Diabetes, and Metabolic Factors in Pancreatic Cancer: A Mendelian Randomization Study
journal: Journal of the National Cancer Institute
author: Carreras-Torres
author_address: Section of Genetics, International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), Lyon, France
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on cancer
rationale: Risk factors for pancreatic cancer include a cluster of metabolic conditions such as obesity, hypertension, dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and type 2 diabetes. Given that these risk factors are correlated, separating out causal from confounded effects is challenging.
exposure_independence: Auhors state GWAS independence threshold. Do not do formal test.
exposure_proxy: Allowed for ambiguos strans but not discussed for other SNPs
n_SNP_difference_reason: Said they used European SNPs but clearly using all ancestry SNPs - only included SNPs that clustered in Retinoic Acid Receptors
power_calculation_how: Power calculations on MR analyses were performed according to Burgess
multiple_testing: Bonferroni correction for 157 tests (tests included for other phenotypes such as height) = 3.2x10-4
limitations_overall: Underpowered for WHR. Deviations from the MR assumptions would bias results to the null. Effects may not be reflective of the extremes of exposure distributions.
limitations_pleiotropy: MR Egger and weighted median did not show evidence of pleiotropy. Neither did funnel plots.
limitations_statistical_power: Not discussed, but sia dthey were underpowered for WHR

title: Effect of increased body mass index on risk of diagnosis or death from cancer
journal: British Journal of Cancer
author: Gharahkhani
author_address: QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute, Brisbane, QLD, Australia
hypothesis: Effect of BMI on overall cancer risk and cancer mortality
rationale: High BMI is strongly associated with increased risk of various cancers.
exposure_study: Puya Gharahkhani  2019 BMI White British adults both
exposure_pleiotropy: To assess this assumption, we repeated the analyses by removing a subset of SNPs that were associated with potential confounders. These were identified by having a Bonferroni-corrected P < 1×10-5 for 520 SNPs tested in nine traits; smoking (four traits), alcohol intake (two traits), coffee/tea consumption (two traits), and height (one trait). In addition, to test for the presence of directional pleiotropy, we used two approaches: (1) we created funnel plots for the MR estimates for all SNPs used as instrumental variable, where asymmetry in the funnel plots indicates directional pleiotropy; and (2) we used the MR Egger regression approach where a non-zero intercept indicates presence of directional pleiotropy.2
exposure_proxy: Not discussed
n_SNP_difference_reason: NA
power_calculation_how: NA
MR_sensitivity_method1: Re-ran analysis using subset of SNPs, having removed SNPs associated with potential confounders
MR_sensitivity_method_results: We repeated the analyses by removing a subset of SNPs that were associated with potential confounders. These were identified by having a Bonferroni-corrected P < 1×10-5 for 520 SNPs tested in nine traits; smoking (four traits), alcohol intake (two traits), coffee/tea consumption (two traits), and height (one trait). In addition, to test for the presence of directional pleiotropy.
multiple_testing: No
limitations_overall: Did not investigate the causal effect of obesity as a dichotomous risk factor. MR model assumed a linear relationship between genetically predicted BMI with cancer risk and mortality. Did not investigate the effect of BMI on cancer mortality in prevalent and incident cancers, separately. Overall cancer phenotype may be rather hetero- geneous
limitations_pleiotropy: Not discussed
limitations_population_stratification: Used a homogenous population with all the participants being of white-British ancestry
limitations_statistical_power: Statistical power was quite low for a conclusive interpretation of the non-significant individual cancer results
